events.name: Fort Collins Android Meeting #1
events.why: Meet everyone, discuss Android technology, apps, devices and development.  Also discuss the group - what to do, formats, ideas for future meetings.

events.why: Take a tour through Google Lab's AppInventor and get your Android dev environment set up!

events.name: What's new in Jelly Bean (4.1) for Developers
events.description:
Let's get together and talk about what's new in Android version 4.1 Jelly Bean for developers and how we see this effecting apps that are out there now and transition strategies.

If you have an app already or are planning to have one, how do you see Jelly Bean effecting you?

We're also looking for people who'd like to give a talk about what they know about 4.1 either via reading, from Google I/O or from transitioning a project to 4.1.

Agenda

6:00 - 6:15p Socializing
6:15 - 6:30p Meeting overview and Announcements
6:30 - 7:30p Jelly Bean overview, new features, discussion
7:30 - 7:45p Closing announcements and future meetings

events.name: The UN-Meetup! Let's talk about what you want to hear
events.description:
The Un-meetup! Let's create a topic backlog!

Come hear 5 minute suggested Android topics you want to hear or learn more about - anything from the best reader apps, intro to android, to designing for multiple screen sizes. We'll have you, the members, talk for about 5 minutes about the topic, why you think it'd be neat for the group and what aspects about the topic interest you. With that, we can see if there are any of us willing to do some research and come back with 15 minutes on the topic for next time!

5:45 - 6:00 : group and area announcements

6:00 - 6:45 : 5 minute topic talks

6:45 - 7:00 : discussion and thoughts

7:00 - 7:45 : networking time

events.name: Learn tips/tricks for Maintainable Java
events.description:
Our main speaker will be Robert Simmons Jr. who will speak on tips and tricks on maintainable Java - a session that's relevant to all of us as Android developers/designers! More about Mr. Simmons, below.

5:45 - 6:00 networking
6:00 - 6:15 welcome and announcements
6:15 - 7:30 Maintainable Java
7:30 - 7:45 networking

Speaker Bio:

Robert Simmons Jr. will present some tips and techniques for writing more maintainable Java code from his second (and recently released) book "Maintainable Java." These techniques are applicable to all types of Java development from Android mobile apps to three tier multimillion dollar software systems. All attendees will leave with a better understanding of the Java language and how to make their lives easier. There will also be a contest for two free copies of "Maintainable Java."

Robert has been working with Java since 1996, wrote his master's dissertation on the structure of the Java language. Recently Robert worked with Samsung international developing the Bluetooth LE API for the new Samsung Galaxy phones.

events.name: Talk about Wearscript!
events.description:
Learn about using Javascript on Google Glass with Wearscript from one of the developers, Scott Greenwald

http://www.wearscript.com/en/latest/

Wearscript (wearscript.com) is an Apache 2.0-licensed platform for Glass development that combines: 
(1) an HTML5 API on Glass for accessing native functionality such as timeline management and sensors

(2) a web-based IDE that can dynamically load code straight onto Glass(es)

(3) a sharing platform for scripts (weariverse.com). 

The philosophy is that because context-aware wearable computing needs to be sufficiently customized to achieve maximum usability and utility, rapid prototyping is particularly important and powerful in the development workflow. Sharing of scripts allows everyone to quickly benefit from and extend others' scripts to suit their own purposes. 

Scott Greenwald is a Phd student in the Fluid Interfaces group at the MIT Media Lab and a member of the OpenShades.com team. He researches design considerations for mobile just-in-time information, from the perspectives of social and psychological phenomena.

events.name: Dart Flight School
events.description:
Dart Flight School event!

Come early at 10:30 to set up! 
11a - 12:30a Tech Talk: Intro to Dart 
1:30p - 2:30p Code Lab: Intermediate Dart 
3:00 - 5:00p Optional Hackathon!

https://www.dartlang.org/events/2013/flight-school/

Thought I'd add a little pep talk about why you really ought to look at Dart.

Dart is one of the most exciting programming languages I’ve encountered in my 33 years of programming.

Here are three strong reasons to use Dart:

1) Dart allows you to do JavaScript programming without the terrible problems inherent in JavaScript. Dart fixes JavaScript’s most serious problems as listed in the book “JavaScript: The Good Parts” by Douglas Crockford. Dart translates to JavaScript that is competitive with the performance of hand-coded JavaScript. 

2) Dart has modern programming features and concise, yet clear syntax. Dart incorporates JavaScript’s best practices into its language design. Dart has: classes, private variables, getter/setters, and convenient syntax for many common use cases. Dart handles the DOM and the rest of its library using modern design patterns (Futures and Streams). It is easy to write maintainable code in Dart. 

3) Dart’s semantics are designed for performance and versatility. Currently, Dart’s VM runs at about twice the speed of the best JavaScript VMs. Remember that on a mobile device, twice the CPU efficiency can mean twice the battery life. Dart’s VM is available in a special version of Chrome called Dartium and can also be used for command line and server-side coding.

Dart has so many benefits it is hard to describe them in a short message. I have a longer version on my blog:

Why Dart Should Be Your Next Programming Language

events.name: Learn about Android Wear
events.description:
Come for an overview of Android Wear, stay for a codelab!
The Android platform has been extended to wearables. You can start building richer wearable experiences for your apps today using the enhanced Notification APIs in this Developer Preview. We'll find out more about design and development principles in this meeting.

We'll have about 45 min or so overview of the design principles of Android Wear and then an hour or so codelab.

If you're interested in doing the codelab, please come with a laptop and sign up for the Android Wear Preview SDK, here: 

developer.android.com/wear/preview/signup.html

For more info about the Android Wear Preview, see: 

developer.android.com/wear/preview

We're grateful to the Loveland Creatorspace who will be hosting us this month - please note the space can hold about 20 people. RSVP on the meetup page, too:

events.name: The future of asynchronous JavaScript programming that you can use now!
events.description:
Learn about the future of asynchronous JavaScript programming, using new features in ECMAScript 6.

These features are available in Chrome, io.js and Firefox today. With node.js support coming soon. You can use these features in older browsers by leveraging ES6 transpilers and soon in TypeScript too. These new features allow you to write asynchronous code that looks like (and maintains like) synchronous code.

The "talk" will will be done in an experimental hands-on fashion, so bring your laptops. It would be best if you had a recent version of Chrome/Firefox installed. If you want to experiment with the transpilers, you'll need to have node.js installed and do an "npm install -g babel".

We will also take a quick look at upcoming ECMAScript 7 features that are expected to be arriving soon in the transpilers.

events.name: TypeScript and Babel
events.description:
This will be a joint meeting with NoCo JavaScript at their usual meeting time and location. Please RSVP here: http://www.meetup.com/NoCo-JavaScript-Meetup/events/222560013/

TypeScript is a JavaScript transpiler that gives you many ECMAScript 6 features today. Additionally, it gives you (optional) type checking. The "talk" will primarily cover TypeScript and why you would want to use it. However, everything shown in TypeScript (except types) will also work in Babel and Babel even gives you some ECMAScript 7 features -- most importantly "async" and "await". So we'll cover that too. You might even want to use TypeScript and Babel in a chain to target specific browser sets, I'll explain why.

Be sure and bring a laptop or Chromebook (or a large tablet with a keyboard) as this "talk" will be interactive, with a series of explanations each followed by a chance for you to try it out.

Please RSVP to: http://www.meetup.com/NoCo-JavaScript-Meetup/events/222560013/

events.name: VR Gallery Touring Software By Belin Fieldson
events.description:
For Google Family Dev Fest, Belin built a demonstration virtual reality gallery which uses Google's cardboard to display pictures taken by the participants, in a VR art gallery. This app accesses a custom nodejs API which stores the images, so it's possible for users to upload pictures, retrieve an access code, and then show the gallery they've created to their friends. The code for the gallery and the API are both public, so anyone who attends will be able to use these technologies to build their own app for Android and iOS. This demonstration is really about understanding the process of making API calls from within Unity, and learning about what APIs do and how they do it.

The VR art gallery code is written in C# using Unity3D IDE, if you want to build your own, it's recommend that you install the latest version of Unity3D ahead of time.

https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download

The node.js code is written in javascript and uses the node package manager. If you want to build your own server, you should have nodejs installed with the latest revision. 

http://nodejs.org

Here are the repos:

Unity VR Gallery in C#: 

https://github.com/thebelin/my-vr-gallery

nodejs API: 

https://github.com/thebelin/gallery-image-api

Belin Fieldson is an independent contractor developer in Fort Collins who hand crafts video games, VR/AR experiences, apps, websites, APIs, jewelry, and electronics. As an avid yo yo thrower who was originally trained in glass blowing in Hawaii by his family, Belin considers art to be extremely important in the development of applications.

events.name: Android's Constraint Layout
events.description:
From the Android Developer Documentation, ConstraintLayout allows you to create large and complex layouts with a flat view hierarchy (no nested view groups). It's similar to RelativeLayout in that all views are laid out according to relationships between sibling views and the parent layout, but it's more flexible than RelativeLayout and easier to use with Android Studio's Layout Editor.

Have you been wanting to know more about the new ConstraintLayout that is now a part of Android? If so, join us at the Armory for a presentation by Brian Sturgill where we will see an example of ConstraintLayout and explore this new addition in Android UI Development.

events.name: Android Things - Interactive Tutorial
events.description:
This month we’ll have a great guest speaker and interactive session - Dave Smith of Google will talk about Android Things and guide us through an interactive tutorial. Space is limited and loaner hardware will be available. Bring a laptop with the latest version of Android Studio installed (see https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html ).

Android Things is a platform that brings the power of Android development to embedded and IoT devices. Android developers can use the SDK, Google services, and development tools they are familiar with to get up and running quickly. In this session, you will learn why Android Things exists and have an opportunity to build your first Android Things application on real hardware.

Agenda

Android Things Overview (30 minutes)

Getting Started Demo (30 minutes)

Hands-on Codelab (60 minutes)

Presenter

Dave Smith is a Developer Advocate at Google, focused on IoT and the Android Things platform. Over the past decade he has worked with low power M2M systems and wireless radio links, and also built custom applications and system components to run Android on embedded platforms. He has a passion for finding opportunities to make devices, and developers, smarter.

events.name: IWD of Northern Colorado 2018

venue.name: Aims Community College Ed Beaty Hall Fireside Lounge

events.description:
We are proud to be hosting the 2018 International Women's Day Celebration, a women's tech conference. This event will highlight the stories of our growing female community of designers, developers, and technology entrepreneurs.

Aims Community College is hosting a networking event with the Google Developer Group and Women Techmakers of Northern Colorado on March 14 in celebration of International Women’s Day. Students, alumni and the community are invited to join Aims on March 14 from 6 to 9 p.m. in the Fireside Lounge in Ed Beaty Hall on the Greeley campus.

The March 14 event will be an opportunity to network, create new friendships, play games and enjoy light refreshments. It will be a celebration of the field of technology and acknowledgment of the amazing contributions of women participating in the technology field.

Aims Associate Professor Jennifer Bailey is a lead organizer of the Google Developer Group and host of the event. After joining Aims in 2011 to teach Mobile Application development, she sought resources in the community to help her learn what the industry knows about technology. When Women Techmakers formed a few years later, Google and the GDG encouraged her to get involved as a woman who works in education and technology.

About the Aims Computer Information Systems (CIS) Program
The Aims Computer Science program offers training in web development, cyber security, networking, database administration, A+ Hardware certification preparation and mobile and desktop application development. Students can earn an A.A.S. degree in Computer Information Systems or Web Design and Development or earn a certificate. More information is available at www.aims.edu/academics/cis.

About Google Developer Group
Google Developer Groups are local groups of developers who are specifically interested in Google products and APIs. Each local group is called a GDG chapter and can host a variety of technical activities for developers, from just a few people getting together to watch our latest videos, to large gatherings with demos and tech talks, to hackathons.

About Women Techmakers
Women Techmakers is Google's global program and brand for women in technology. Kicked off in 2012 by then VP of Google[x], Megan Smith, Women Techmakers is now led by Women in Technology Advocate Natalie Villalobos and a global team of Googlers who are passionate about empowering women in technology through increased visibility, community and resources.

About Aims Community College
Aims Community College is one of the most progressive two-year colleges in Colorado. Founded more than 50 years ago in Greeley, Aims has since established locations in Fort Lupton, Loveland and Windsor. Curriculum now includes 4,000 day, evening, weekend and online courses annually in more than 200 degree and certificate programs. Aims Community College is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission. Aims Community College is an Equal Employment Opportunity Employer and an Equal Opportunity Educational Institution. www.aims.edu

events.name: Build apps for the Google Assistant with Actions on Google

venue.name: Aims Community College Ed Beaty Hall Fireside Lounge

events.description:
Build Actions for your Community

Writing an app for the Google Assistant with DialogFlow is a really fun and interactive challenge.

Lets explore the Google Actions for the Community program and resources that teach developers how to write Actions for the Google Assistant.

I will demonstrate how to create and test a simple Action using DialogFlow and web based tools. No prior experience or knowledge necessary.

Food and Beverages will be provided.

We will be meeting in the Fireside Lounge computer lab in Ed Beaty Hall room 127 (North East side of the building) on the Greeley campus at Aims Community College.

events.name: Build Actions for Your Community Kick Off Event Party
events.description: Would you like to win a Google Home or Google Home Mini? Do you have a great idea about an Action to build for the Google Assistant? Or would you just like to learn more and collaborate with us on our Action building journey? If so, Join us and participate in a Hackathon to Build Actions for the Community for the Google Assistant. Bring laptops and I will show you how to get started with new Codelabs, code resources and examples. Do you have a great idea for an Assistant App? You may choose to sign up for the hackathon or just join us to socialize and learn more about making Actions for the Google Assistant. No formal code experience is required to build a great app for the Google Assistant, which makes this a fun hackathon for all levels of experience. Let's explore what's new with Dialogflow as of I/O '18 and build some apps! Winners will be announced and prizes handed out at Part Two of this series, one week from this meetup.

events.name: Build Actions for Your Community Prizes and App Showcase
events.description: Time to announce winners and present prizes to the participants of our Build Actions for Your Community event! Come to collect your prize or celebrate with the winners. Let's talk about our ideas and discuss what we learned and share in our experience developing Google Actions!

events.name: DevFest Fairgrounds
events.description:
~ Joint Event with GDG Boulder Join and RSVP Below as Space Is Limited ~

https://www.meetup.com/Google-Developer-Group-Boulder/events/253077832/

Come to DevFest Fairgrounds for a fun day of hands-on coding to learn some cool new Google tech!

We’ll start the day with a 15-minute talk on each of our three topics: TensorFlow, Google Actions and Flutter.

9:00 AM Welcome
9:05 AM Introduction to TensorFlow
9:20 AM Introduction to Google Actions
9:35 AM Introduction to Flutter
9:50 AM Break

Then we’ll start coding! There will be booths for each of the topics where you can sit down and go through a codelab or work on your own project, with people around you to help.

We’ll do pomodoro-style rotation, where you code for 45 minutes and then take a 15 minute break. There will be carnival games set up, so those breaks are going to be fun!

10:00 AM Code
10:45 AM Break
11:00 AM Code
11:45 AM Break
12:00 PM Code
12:45 PM Lunch
2:00 PM Code
2:45 PM Break
3:00 PM Code
3:45 PM Show-and-tell
5:00 PM End of event

At the end of the day, we’ll have a show-and-tell to share what we’re working on.

events.name: Halloween Spooktacular Party with Aims and GDG NoCo
events.description:
Everyone is invited to the brand new annual Halloween Bash brought to you by Google Developer Group of Northern Colorado! Costumes encouraged but not required. Let's meet at Aims campus for a quick snack and some out of the ordinary Halloween treats! Then at 6pm we can frequent the local establishments for code and conversation!

We are excited to see you at this year's event!

About Aims Loveland Campus
The Aims Loveland Campus has been located in the heart of downtown Loveland for over 30 years. It offers a comprehensive education with personal attention to help students succeed. Students can choose from an Associate of Arts degree, Associate of Art Business Transfer degree, Graphic Software and Applications certificate, Basic Animation certificate and various Arts and Science courses. For more information about the campus please visit www.aims.edu/campus/lovelandor email [masked].

About Aims Community College
Aims Community College is one of the most progressive two-year colleges in Colorado. Founded in 1967 in Greeley, Aims has since established locations in Fort Lupton, Loveland and Windsor. Curriculum now includes 4,000 day, evening, weekend and online courses annually in more than 160 degree and certificate programs. Aims Community College is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission. Aims Community College is an Equal Employment Opportunity Employer and an Equal Opportunity Educational Institution. www.aims.edu

About Google Developer Group
GDGs are local groups of developers who are specifically interested in Google products and APIs. Each local group is called a GDG chapter and can host a variety of technical activities for developers - from just a few people getting together to watch our latest videos, to large gatherings with demos and tech talks, to hackathons.

events.name: GDG DevFest Family Programming Event (4th annual)
events.description:
Please see this event on the GDG Denver meetup page to RSVP:
https://www.meetup.com/GDG-Denver/events/250831413/

#ColoradoDevFest

An Eventbrite ticket is required for this event, please get one here:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/colorado-devfest-2018-family-edition-tickets-49767132834

Photos from past years can be seen here:
2017 (https://photos.app.goo.gl/eQoq4zVEUCiVM7K03)
2016 (https://goo.gl/photos/ZNoj6iTG9LewdUis5)
2015 (https://goo.gl/photos/Yu85r1UMTyn3FSJp8)

Mentors/volunteers (GDG members) this is a great opportunity to help out with exploration stations and encourage the future generations of tech elite! Get in touch if you want to help out.

Calling all kids interested in tech, come on out!

events.name: Code and Coffee
events.description:
Please join me at Zoe's coffee shop in Greeley if you would like to study and work on programming projects with a buddy or multiple buddies. I have many projects to work on currently and I need some community for accountability, motivation, fun and learning.

So please come out to Zoe's regardless of what project or platform you are working on if you would like to hang out in a group study coffee shop environment.

Currently I am working on many projects, specifically I am studying Kotlin, practicing Android development, trying to publish an app in Swift, and writing Actions for the Google Assistant.

Please come keep me company, motivate me, or help me to procrastinate.

events.name: IWD of Northern Colorado 2019
events.description:
We are proud to be hosting a 2019 International Women's Day Celebration sponsored by Women Techmakers and Aims Community College. This event will highlight the stories of our growing female community of designers, developers, and technology entrepreneurs.

One of the most powerful thing women can do for other women in the field of technology is to simply share our stories.

We would love to hear about your experience in technology! We would like to collect 2 to 5 min. stories from women who would like to share their experience with us. We would like to record and post the stories to youtube for other women around the world. The first 10 women volunteers to share their story will be awarded a very special gift bag (worth up to 15$). We will be providing refreshments and possibly other schwag for all participants, even those who do not want to share. Join us anyway!

Please come and contribute your story or hear the stories of others and celebrate women in technology at this event. All women in technology are invited to join us at Aims on April 26 from 6 to 8 pm in the Ed Beaty theater.

About Aims:
Aims Associate Professor Jennifer Bailey is an organizer of the Google Developer Group and host of the event. After joining Aims in 2011 to teach Mobile Application development, she sought resources in the community to help her learn what the industry knows about technology. When Women Techmakers formed a few years later, Google and the GDG encouraged her to get involved as a woman who works in education and technology.

About the Aims Computer Information Systems (CIS) Program
The Aims Computer Science program offers training in web development, cyber security, networking, database administration, A+ Hardware certification preparation and mobile and desktop application development. Students can earn an A.A.S. degree in Computer Information Systems or Web Design and Development or earn a certificate. More information is available at www.aims.edu/academics/cis.

About Google Developer Group
Google Developer Groups are local groups of developers who are specifically interested in Google products and APIs. Each local group is called a GDG chapter and can host a variety of technical activities for developers, from just a few people getting together to watch our latest videos, to large gatherings with demos and tech talks, to hackathons.

About Women Techmakers
Women Techmakers is Google's global program and brand for women in technology. Kicked off in 2012 by then VP of Google[x], Megan Smith, Women Techmakers is now led by Women in Technology Advocate Natalie Villalobos and a global team of Googlers who are passionate about empowering women in technology through increased visibility, community and resources.

About Aims Community College
Aims Community College is one of the most progressive two-year colleges in Colorado. Founded more than 50 years ago in Greeley, Aims has since established locations in Fort Lupton, Loveland and Windsor. Curriculum now includes 4,000 day, evening, weekend and online courses annually in more than 200 degree and certificate programs. Aims Community College is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission. Aims Community College is an Equal Employment Opportunity Employer and an Equal Opportunity Educational Institution. www.aims.edu

events.name: GCP Cloud Study Jam!

venue.name: Front Range Community College - Larimer Campus

events.description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin? Join us for our Cloud Study Jam!

Get official Google training, a $55+ value, free of charge. Together we'll work through several Google Cloud labs, starting with an intro to the Google Cloud Platform. You will get hands-on experience with the Cloud Console, Kubernetes, Security, and Machine Learning.

Then after our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to compete any labs you want.

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

Agenda (TBD)
5:30pm: Welcome & get free access to Qwiklabs
5:45 pm Lab 1: Creating a Virtual Machine
6:30 pm Lab 2: Kubernetes Engine Qwik Start
7:00 pm Break
7:15 pm Lab 3: your choice (Network/Load Balancers, Cloud ML)
8:00 pm Event ends - THANK YOU!
events.how_to_find_us:
Front Range Community College, Mount Antero Building, Room 552
Student Success Center

events.name: DevFest Fairgrounds
events.description:
~ Joint event with GDG Boulder ~

************************************************************
* THIS IS A REPOSTED EVENT
* PLEASE RSVP ON BOULDER'S MEETUP PAGE
* THE LINK IS BELOW
************************************************************

https://www.meetup.com/Google-Developer-Group-Boulder/events/263441485/

Come to DevFest Fairgrounds for a fun day of hands-on coding to learn some cool new Google tech!

Details to come. Meanwhile, watch a summary video of last year's event to get a taste: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YnRLpP_ulng

events.name: Holiday Party with Google Developer Group NoCo!
events.description:
Happy Holidays from GDG Noco! This year I am throwing a Google Actions themed, casual get together at Zoe's Coffee in Greeley! Come and join me for a quick and casual get together at the end of the semester. Zoe's has wifi, so bring your laptop if you like!

FOR GDG ONLY (GDG is open to all community members who care to join): In order to participate in the optional festive activity (contest), please find a neat Google Action that you can share with the group and tell us about it. The directory of all Actions for the Google Assistant can be found at https://assistant.google.com/explore/. Holiday themed Actions are encouraged but not required. The Google Assistant can be used on both Android or iPhone or a myriad of other devices if you'd like to try some out. A great idea for a Holiday Action that doesn't exist yet also qualifies. Those who participate by telling us about an Action or great idea for an Action will qualify to win a prize, judging will take place by 7pm.

Zoe's is a casual atmosphere with a wide variety of tea/coffee beverages and a limited selection of snacks that can be purchased. Beverages/food are not provided by GDG, but the prices at Zoe's are quite reasonable.

I will go early and try to reserve us a table so look for me! Hope to see you there!

events.name: Coding @ Coffee Shops!
events.description:
I have many coding projects to work on in the upcoming weeks, so if you'd like to join me in a very nice environment head on down to the coffee shop and bring a project!

Currently I'm working on writing small projects for Android using Kotlin, iOS, C#, and I'm building small sample projects that demonstrate the newest Google Action features. Participants may bring whatever projects they like!

events.name: Coding @ Coffee Shops!
events.description:
I have many coding projects to work on in the upcoming weeks, so if you'd like to join me in a very nice environment head on down to the coffee shop and bring a project!

Currently I'm working on writing small projects for Android using Kotlin, iOS, C#, and I'm building small sample projects that demonstrate the newest Google Action features. Participants may bring whatever projects they like!

answers.question: Tell us your Google-related usage or development background
answers.answer: I purchased a tablet and wrote a few sample programs for it to see how it works. I will be learning more in the near future. I will be developing and teaching a mobile apps certificate program at Aims Community College. I have 10 years as a software developer in various languages and platforms.

answers.question: What is your favorite app? (web, android, etc.)
answers.answer: I know this is silly but I really enjoy plants vs zombies on my tablet lol

answers.question: What would you most like to learn or share at the Google Developers Group?
answers.answer: I just love to share ideas and hear people talk about the subject matter. It would be great to meet and talk with professionals doing development so I can get a feel for what the industry is looking for, professional contacts for recruiting and general purposes, and who doesn't love to hang out an talk about coding? lol

group_profile.intro: Hello, my name is Jenn, I'm a computer science professor at Aims Community college and have been teaching a mobile apps certificate program there for 5 years. I am fascinated by the world of mobile applications, Android in particular.

answers.question: Tell us your Google-related usage or development background
What is your favorite app? (web, android, etc.)
What would you most like to learn or share at the Google Developers Group?
Tell us your Google-related usage or development background
answers.answer: I am a Mac/iOS user primarily, but I use Google Apps and want to learn to program for Android

answers.question: What is your favorite app? (web, android, etc.)
What would you most like to learn or share at the Google Developers Group?
answers.answer: I’m most interested in meeting others who create apps or want to learn

organizers.name: Tara P.
organizers.bio: I am a 20-year-old woman who loves coding. I love learning new things, new software, and new programming languages. Outside of Meetup, I am a member of Phi Theta Kappa; Beta Kappa Lambda chapter. I graduate this May.
